Award.AbstractNarration:
This objective of this research is to employ a revolutionary sensor design paradigm inspired by the natural photosynthesis process of plants/algae. The Bio-Inspired Sensing using Optoelectronic Nanocomposites (BISON) sensing platform utilizes specific wavelengths of light or photonic energy to generate photocurrent directly correlated to structural strain for structural monitoring applications. Phase I of this project focuses on nanocomposite fabrication and laboratory-based sensing performance characterization. Instead of using them as point sensors, Phase II of this research integrates the BISON coatings with an inverse spatial mapping algorithm for achieving a truly distributed sensor capable of directly measuring 2D structural strain fields. Upon experimental validation of the sensor's capabilities to detect and monitor non-uniform strain fields, cracks, and impact damage, Phase III focuses on large-scale structural testing and field validation.

The research outcomes will have potential for advancing the technological state-of-art and scientific knowledge in areas such as nanocomposites, optoelectronics, sensors, inverse algorithms, and structural health monitoring. The BISON sensing system can also enhance civil infrastructure safety and advance condition-based health monitoring techniques. A detailed education and outreach plan is also included to broaden the participation of under-represented students, while the outcomes of this research will be incorporated in current and new undergrad/grad engineering courses.

ProgramReference.Text: SENSORS AND SENSOR SYSTEMS FOR CIS

POR.DRECONTENT:
Throughout the course of modern history, numerous catastrophic accidents occurred and were results of damage occurring and accumulating in structures, namely civil infrastructure, aircraft, naval vessels, wind turbines, and offshore structures. These sudden structural failures caused severe socioeconomic losses, and in many cases, loss of lives. As such, the need for reliable prognosis of the health of structural systems promoted the development of sensing technologies capable of simultaneously detecting multiple types of damage. However, conventional sensors are designed to only measure a specific structural response (e.g., strain, displacement, or acceleration). This limitation forces one to use a wide variety of sensors densely instrumented on a given structure, which results in high overhead costs, instrumentation challenges, and requires extensive signal processing of sensor raw data. Often, the end result is that only a limited number of sensors could be sparsely instrumented in a structure, and the ability to monitor structural changes (e.g., due to damage) becomes severely limited.

 

In this project, a transformative approach to sensing structural damage was investigated. The objective of this research was to engineer a multifunctional, self-sensing, structural coating that could selectively detect different types of structural damage precursors using a single platform. A materials-based sensing approach was employed in lieu of the conventional method of building sensors from mechanical or electrical assemblies. In that regard, a coating was designed that incorporated multiple layers of conductive polymers that were sensitive to light and to different damage phenomena (Figs. 1 and 2). Because the coating was also the sensor, it could be fabricated as large as necessary, coated onto complex structural surfaces, and used for various engineering applications. In addition, since everywhere in the material was sensitive to damage, this technology enabled spatial sensing of damage, as was demonstrated as part of this project. While early investigations focused on spin-coating small-scale specimens for laboratory testing, an inkjet-printing prototype was developed in a latter phase. Inkjet printing allowed the deposition of films onto virtually any surface and enabled high throughput, scalable, advanced manufacturing of larger-scale, flexible sensors.

 

The self-sensing coating was multifunctional, as it was specifically designed to possess multiple engineering functionalities. First, the coating was photoactive and could generate electrical current when illuminated by light for power harvesting applications (Fig. 3). Second, the generated electrical current was also sensitive to the type of damage and its severity. In particular, when the coating was illuminated using blue light (Fig. 4), the generated current was shown to be proportional to structural deformation (Fig. 5), which could be used for monitoring changes in structural shape, impact damage, or cracks. On the other hand, when illuminated by infrared light, the coatings electrical current was only sensitive to pH (Fig. 6). Here, pH monitoring (from a structures perspective) is important, since changes in pH is indicative of corrosion. As a result, one could monitor different types of damage phenomena using one material-based sensing platform and with different colored light sources. The coating was also self-sensing in that it does not require external power to operate.

 

In general, the results obtained from this research enhanced current knowledge in photoactive materials, multifunctional systems, and sensor technology. The results showed that it was possible to create thin coatings that could simultaneously and selectively sense different types of damage (and its severity) in structural systems.
